name: IMRC
mission: Help India's muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, equality and their rights as citizens of India
theoryOfChange: IMRC publishes annual and impact reports that serve as program strategy documents, detailing their mission, objectives, and how their programs aim to create change. For instance, the 2019 Impact Report outlines their mission to help India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, and equality, and states their approach to poverty alleviation through awareness, education, skill development, healthcare, and relief. These reports describe their various programs, such as education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief, and provide measurable outcomes and impact figures. The 2021 Annual Report also mentions the importance of strategic planning for the organization's future direction.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 39/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Build working capital reserves to 1-3 months of operating expenses
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities earns 68/100 due to strong alignment and good impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: The IMRC USA website has dedicated sections such as "Give your Zakat" and "Calculating Your Zakat". Additionally, "Zakat/ Poor Feeding" is listed as one of their program areas. The website also states, "Zakat must be used to directly assist those in need; a few examples are feeding them, clothing them, sheltering them or educating them." and "Your gift is invested, and the returns help the poor and needy year after year." (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQF7Ej-AO_yVXHxOXiKN3-u5MzYca6I4MpxBSDsn_R4xk8lz5bR-QKeBdYrOunhzeBh8GZO7V5mdfALDYtgx_ltsmDY397Er2tzwjYt2Yr4FrK1szg==)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%.
IMRC holds 55.7 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.01 per $1 raised.
IMRC provides access to safe water and medical treatment for patients in India.
The organization supports students and provides meals to vulnerable populations.
IMRC continued its healthcare and education programs, reporting on patients treated and students supported.
The charity manages seasonal programs including Ramadan and Qurbani food distribution.
IMRC constructs wells and provides healthcare services as part of its direct service impact.
The organization offers Zakat-eligible donation options for its various relief programs.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 68/100 score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and strong alignment with humanitarian needs in India, though its impact score is moderated by the lack of external cost-effectiveness data.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact evaluations to verify long-term outcomes
Data confidence is medium, suggesting a need for more transparent reporting on specific beneficiary metrics

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 39/50, the charity shows high donor fit for those seeking to support vulnerable minorities in India [8]. The organization's Zakat-eligible status and long track record of addressing urgent humanitarian needs through Ramadan and Qurbani programs reinforce its strong communal alignment [5][6].
dimension_explanations.impact: IMRC demonstrates a direct service model, providing healthcare, education, and emergency relief to thousands of beneficiaries annually [3][5]. While the organization reports significant outputs—such as treating patients and supporting students—the impact score of 31/50 reflects a lack of standardized cost-per-beneficiary data and third-party verification [1][7].

baseline_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides critical humanitarian aid and social services to empower India's Muslim and minority communities.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.8% indicating efficient use of funds for direct services
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with only $0.01 spent to raise every $1
Strong liquidity with 55.7 months of working capital available
Verified Zakat-eligible status for Muslim donors
baseline_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) works to help India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, and equality through comprehensive social programs [1][4]. The organization reported a total revenue of $13,833,809 and maintains a high program expense ratio of 89.8%, ensuring the majority of funds directly support its mission [1][2].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 68/100 score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and strong alignment with humanitarian needs in India, though its impact score is moderated by the lack of external cost-effectiveness data.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization has seen a <cite id="16">3-year revenue CAGR of -10.2%</cite>, suggesting a need to diversify or revitalize its donor base.
While output numbers are high, there is <cite id="17">no evidence of external evaluations</cite> or third-party impact studies to verify long-term outcomes.

bbb_assessment.summary: Financial statements are audited, but the organization is not currently evaluated against all 20 BBB standards.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's massive asset base and 40+ year history mitigate short-term financial risks.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="16">negative revenue growth</cite> and a <cite id="17">lack of third-party verified impact data</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data but limited external impact validation.

alignment.explanation: IMRC is highly aligned with Muslim donors, specifically serving <cite id="11">zakat-eligible categories like the poor and needy</cite> in a <cite id="21">high-urgency humanitarian context</cite>.

credibility.explanation: IMRC is a long-standing institution with a <cite id="13">fully independent board</cite> and <cite id="14">substantial net assets</cite> exceeding $48 million. It maintains high transparency regarding its <cite id="18">zakat-eligible status</cite>.
credibility.improvement: Credibility could be enhanced by <cite id="17">seeking external evaluations</cite> to move beyond self-reported impact metrics.

impact.explanation: The charity operates a <cite id="19">direct service model</cite> with a <cite id="5">high historical program ratio</cite>, though recent filings show a <cite id="4">89.8% ratio</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact scoring would improve by <cite id="20">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> in a standardized format to enable cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct implementation of social and relief programs

rich_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides critical humanitarian aid and social services to empower India's Muslim and minority communities.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the long-term resilience of Muslim minorities in India through an established institution with massive financial stability.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations for the poor in India
Value long-term institutional stability over rapid growth
Prefer direct service delivery in healthcare and education
Seek organizations with very low fundraising overhead
giving_considerations: The organization is currently in a revenue contraction phase
Large asset reserves mean your gift contributes to a very stable 'endowment-like' environment
Impact is reported as broad outputs rather than verified long-term outcomes
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-growth startups or those who require independent RCT evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent internal reporting of outputs (meals, students, patients) without external validation.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMRC uses a multi-sectoral approach (health, water, education) to alleviate poverty and secure rights for minorities in India.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that large-scale grain distribution and medical treatments lead to measurable improvements in community health and economic status.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Despite large reserves, the scale of poverty in India and the recent decline in revenue suggest a high need for new funding to maintain program levels.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: India (Jammu and Kashmir and various states)

peer_comparison.differentiator: IMRC stands out for its <cite id="12">extreme liquidity (55 months of capital)</cite> compared to the <cite id="22">peer median program expense ratio of 89.8%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization spends only <cite id="6">$0.01 for every $1 raised</cite>, ensuring that donor contributions are not consumed by high marketing costs.
IMRC maintains <cite id="12">55.7 months of working capital</cite>, providing extreme organizational stability and the ability to sustain programs during economic downturns.
Impact reports demonstrate the ability to scale, such as treating <cite id="8">183,100 patients</cite> and supporting over <cite id="7">16,000 students</cite> in a single year.

strengths_deep_dive: IMRC's strength lies in its deep-rooted infrastructure within India, allowing for massive distribution of aid. Their 2020 data shows the distribution of <cite id="10">16,455,840 meals</cite> and the provision of water access to <cite id="9">587,000 individuals</cite>. This scale is supported by a <cite id="13">100% independent board</cite> that oversees <cite id="14">$48.7 million in total assets</cite>, ensuring that the organization has the resources to meet its mission of helping minorities achieve <cite id="15">security, freedom, and equality</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1981</cite>, Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) is a humanitarian organization dedicated to supporting India’s Muslim and minority communities through <cite id="2">education, healthcare, and emergency relief</cite>. The organization operates with a significant financial footprint, reporting <cite id="3">$13,833,809 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year. IMRC demonstrates high operational efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 89.8%</cite> according to its latest filings, while Charity Navigator data indicates a historical <cite id="5">program expense ratio of 89.8%</cite>. Their fundraising model is exceptionally lean, spending only <cite id="6">$0.01 to raise every $1</cite>. Beyond immediate relief, IMRC invests in long-term human capital; in 2021 alone, the organization <cite id="7">supported 16,493 students</cite> and provided medical care to <cite id="8">183,100 patients</cite>. The charity's reach is extensive, providing <cite id="9">safe water access to 587,000 people</cite> in 2020 and distributing over <cite id="10">16 million meals</cite> during the same period. By focusing on the <cite id="11">fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy)</cite> within India, IMRC provides a vital lifeline for marginalized populations seeking security and equality.
